Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Story:
I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, the invitation to the upcoming brainstorming session open in one window, and my mom’s text in another. “Don’t forget, we’re making dumplings together on Saturday. Grandma’s coming!” she wrote, a string of heart emojis trailing behind her words. My family always made a big deal out of these traditions, especially when Grandma visited. I knew how much it meant to them, to her, that I was there, hands dusted with flour, laughing and sharing stories.

But the brainstorming session was scheduled for the same afternoon. Technically, it was optional, but I knew how these things worked. The product team expected developers to show up, to contribute ideas, to show initiative. I’d been trying to prove myself, to be seen as someone who cared about more than just code. Missing it might mean missing out on a chance to be heard, to be part of something new.

I felt the pressure building in my chest, torn between the warmth of my family’s kitchen and the bright, collaborative energy of my team. Both worlds wanted me, and I didn’t know how to choose.
